title: 113_hr4496
content: The Act may be cited as the "Covering People With Pre-Existing Conditions Act of 2014" and establishes universal access programs to improve high-risk pools and reinsurance markets for individuals with pre-existing conditions. Each State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments. Each State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments. The State funds derived from State premium assessments not used on State health care programs can be used for this purpose. States not operating a qualified high risk pool must establish one to meet the requirement. The State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments. If a State does not operate a qualified high-risk pool, it must establish one to meet the requirement. The State's operation of the reinsurance program will be treated as the operation of a qualified high-risk pool for certain purposes. State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments. If a State does not operate a qualified high-risk pool, it must establish one to meet the requirement. The State's operation of the reinsurance program will be treated as the operation of a qualified high-risk pool for certain purposes. The State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments. If a State does not operate a qualified high-risk pool, it must establish one to meet the requirement. The State may use premium assessment funds to transition from operating a high-risk pool to a qualified State reinsurance program if the pool is in strong fiscal health. For a State to meet the requirement of a qualified State reinsurance program, it must be in strong fiscal health as determined by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners and approved by the State Insurance Commissioner. A qualified State reinsurance program in the small group market can offer coverage on a prospective or retrospective basis to protect health insurance issuers against annual aggregate spending and individual catastrophic costs. This program must also satisfy HIPAA requirements. A qualified State reinsurance program in the small group market can offer coverage for enrollees and purchase protection against individual catastrophic costs. It must satisfy HIPAA requirements and be deemed a qualified high-risk pool under the Public Health Service Act. The program must provide at least two coverage options, including a high deductible health plan. The pool must have stable funding, eliminate waiting lists, and offer coverage options including a high deductible health plan with a health savings account. It must also cover individuals who face a 24-month disability waiting period. The pool must allow coverage for individuals facing a 24-month disability waiting period and limit premiums to 150% of the average standard risk rates in the State. Education and outreach initiatives are also required for residents and brokers to understand the pool. The high-risk pool must provide coverage for preventive services and disease management for chronic diseases. Only citizens and nationals of the United States are eligible to participate in the pool. Education and outreach initiatives are necessary for residents and brokers to understand the pool's availability. To participate in a qualifying State high risk pool receiving funds, the State must certify that all applicants provide documentation of citizenship or nationality. To qualify for a State high risk pool receiving funds, individuals must provide documentation of citizenship or nationality as required by the Social Security Act. The Secretary must maintain records to verify this information only once per individual. Starting January 1, 2015, a pool must be a qualifying State high risk pool to be eligible under the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary may waive requirements for State reinsurance programs and high risk pools under section 2745 of the Public Health Service Act. $15 billion is appropriated for fiscal years 2015-2024 for this purpose. The Act allocates $15 billion for fiscal years 2015-2024 and an additional $10 billion for fiscal years 2020-2024 for health insurance coverage. Definitions for "health insurance coverage" and "health insurance issuer" are provided in section 2791 of the Public Health Service Act. The term "current section 2745 qualified high risk pool" is also defined. The term "current section 2745 qualified high risk pool" is defined under the Public Health Service Act as in effect as of the date of the enactment of this Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The term "standard risk rate" is a rate determined under the State high risk pool by considering premium rates charged by other health insurers. The term "standard risk rate" is a rate determined under the State high risk pool by considering premium rates charged by other health insurance issuers, using actuarial techniques, and reflecting anticipated claims experience and expenses for the coverage involved. The term "State" refers to any of the 50 States or the District of Columbia.
